Efficient Inference of Rankings From Multi-Body Comparisons

Paper Code

This paper introduces a generalization of the efficient iterative step developed by Mark Newman for the Bradley-Terry (BT) model, extending its application from two-entity interactions to multi-body interactions (Plackett-Luce). The BT probabilistic model, similar to the Elo rating system used in chess, is an algorithm for computing player strength scores.

Two-Entity vs. Multi-Body Interactions

Two-entity games involve head-to-head interactions between two teams, players, or entities, such as soccer matches or boxing matches. In contrast, multi-body interactions encompass scenarios involving more than two entities, such as Formula One racing or tournaments.

Extending the Bradley-Terry Model

To accommodate these higher-order interactions, we employ hypergraphs, a generalization of standard graphs, as well as an expansion of the likelihood function as the framework of adapting the efficient schema of the BT model for multi-body interactions. This extension allows for quicker estimation of player strength scores in complex multi-entity competitions.

The experiments were conducted on both real preference data and synthetically generated datasets, enabling a more comprehensive analysis of the capabilities of this model.

Energy Volatility Forecasting & Regime-Aware Risk Monitoring

Dsahboard Code

Overview

I built an end-to-end system to forecast and monitor energy-sector volatility (XLE) using econometric models and regime-switching dynamics, deployed in a fully automated cloud environment. The project integrates financial, macroeconomic, and exogenous data to support daily risk assessment and volatility-conditioned decision making.

Originally developed for a Financial Econometrics course, the system was extended into a production-style pipeline with automated retraining, evaluation, and dashboarding.

Data & Features

  • Market data: intraday prices (15-minute bars) to compute realized variance
  • Macroeconomic signals: interest rates, volatility indices (VIX, OVX), energy prices
  • Exogenous features: weather anomaly z-scores and extreme-event flags

All data is versioned and stored in a bronze / silver / gold S3 data-lake structure for reproducibility.

Modeling

I implemented and benchmarked multiple econometric volatility models:

  • EWMA
  • GARCH
  • HAR-RV

Models are retrained on rolling windows and evaluated strictly out-of-sample using QLIKE. To capture structural changes in volatility, I added a Markov regime-switching model to infer latent Low / Medium / High volatility states and track regime persistence and transition risk.

System & Deployment

  • Dockerized pipelines on AWS ECS Fargate
  • EventBridge for scheduled daily execution
  • S3, Glue, and Athena for analytics-ready storage
  • Power BI dashboards for forecasts, regimes, and performance metrics

The system runs fully automatically and produces daily, versioned outputs for risk monitoring.

Key Takeaways

  • Translates econometric theory into a production-grade system
  • Emphasizes automation, reproducibility, and out-of-sample validation
  • Designed for real-world risk monitoring, not just point forecasting

Tools: Python, Pandas, Statsmodels, AWS (S3, ECS, EventBridge, Glue, Athena), Docker, Power BI

End-To-End Machine Learning Apartment Price Prediction Model

Code

This project consisted of two major components: data engineering and machine learning modeling.

Data Engineering

I built a data pipeline to retrieve publicly available apartment listings using web scraping. I developed bots to scrape HTML content for listings in a given city, parsing the extracted data and storing it as a JSON file. To structure the data effectively, I designed an Entity-Relationship Diagram (ERD) and implemented a SQLite3 relational database, ensuring robust data integrity through Pydantic for validation. This approach was necessary to ensure accurate predictions at scale.

Machine Learning Modeling & Analysis

The second phase of the project focused on analyzing the data and developing predictive models. Through Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA), I identified trends and challenges in real-world data quality. I then built three machine learning models:

  • XGBoost (Extreme Gradient Boosted Trees)
  • Standard Neural Network
  • Lasso Regression

Given the limited numerical data available from HTML content, I sought to enhance model accuracy by incorporating text-based features. I processed amenity descriptions using TF-IDF (Term Frequency–Inverse Document Frequency) to transform text into numerical representations. This feature engineering approach led to a 55% reduction in the average squared error, significantly improving predictive performance.

Distributed Matrix Multiplication with Map-Reduce on GCP

Code

With the massive rise in the popularity of Machine Learning, the need for efficient computation has become paramount. In the Engineering Cloud Computing class, we were tasked with leveraging Google's Map-Reduce architecture to distribute workloads across multiple virtual machines.

Project Overview

To explore distributed computing efficiency, I first identified and recreated a research paper that analyzed the performance of different matrix multiplication schemas. This involved designing an orchestration system to efficiently partition matrices into smaller chunks.

Implementation on Google Cloud Platform

Each matrix was appropriately split into chunks, ensuring that each pair of submatrices was distributed to Google Cloud Platform's (GCP) serverless functions for parallel computation. After processing, the results were aggregated to reconstruct the final matrix, demonstrating the scalability and efficiency of serverless architectures in large-scale computations. This scheme was on average 8x faster than the standard matrix multiplication method using GCP.

Image Classifier using CNN (Convolutional Neural Network)

Code

The FashionMNIST dataset consists of images representing various clothing types. To process this dataset, I first loaded the data, ensuring that each image was represented as an array of pixel values.

To reduce computational complexity, I applied Principal Component Analysis (PCA) to lower the dimensionality of the image data while retaining key features. This optimization significantly improved efficiency in model training.

Using the processed dataset, I designed and trained a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) to classify images into their respective clothing categories. After 20 epochs of training, the model achieved an 90% accuracy in correctly identifying clothing classes.

Credit Card Fraud Detection Using Ensemble Voting

Code

I trained multiple classification algorithms, including Support Vector Machine (SVM), Random Forest, and Logistic Regression, to predict fraudulent credit card transactions of European card holders. To enhance predictive performance, I combined these models using ensemble methods.

While all of the models performed well, the ensemble soft voting performed the best achieving a 98% accuracy in fraud detection. The predictions were based on 14 anonymized features.

It is important to note that the features in the dataset were strong predictors, and such high accuracy may not be achievable when working with the challenges of real-world data. However, this assignment provided me with hands-on experience in using ensemble methods, which could be valuable in practical applications.

Dataset

The dataset used for this project was sourced from Kaggle: Credit Card Fraud Detection Dataset (2023) .

Equipment Rental Interface

Code

The full-stack website includes an interface for employees and customers of an equipment rental business. HTML, CSS, and Bootstrap ensure the site is user-friendly and provides a good user experience (UX). Through a Python (Flask) backend, the website allows employees to efficiently manage business operations, such as renting equipment to customers. The backend tracks and updates the MySQL database, enabling small businesses to streamline their operations, improve organization, and minimize human error.

Group Interactions of Professional Golf Players

Code

Through the use of Network Science, I modeled the performance of PGA (Professional Golf Association) players when grouped with others. The intuition for this project came from the "Tiger Effect," a phenomenon in which the large crowds following Tiger Woods caused his playing partners to struggle as a result.

This project was conducted using a combination of datasets—one provided by DataGolf, a website that explores data science in professional golf, and another obtained through web scraping. I used the Selenium library to simulate human interactions, specifically iterating through a dropdown menu containing different tournament years to gather relevant information.

The collected data was then analyzed using statistical methods to model the relative performance changes when players were paired with different partners. The result was a graph modeling the interactions between different player pairings.
